clinical_study.official_title: Microdialysis of Paraspinal Muscle in Healthy Volunteers and Patients Underwent Posterior Lumbar Fusion Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Paraspinal muscle damage is inevitable during conventional posterior lumbar fusion surgery. Minimal invasive surgery is postulated to result in less muscle damage and better outcome. The aim of this study is to monitor metabolic changes of the paraspinal muscle and to evaluate paraspinal muscle damage during surgery using microdialysis (MD).

detailed_description.textblock: Posterior approach is a common and important surgical procedure for various lumbar diseases. Owing to the anatomy, the damage of paraspinal muscle is inevitable during conventional posterior lumbar fusion surgery. Degeneration and malfunction of the paraspinal muscle might associate with pain and inferior postoperative clinical outcome.

primary_outcome.description: To study whether the glucerol concentration can be used to evaluate surgery related paraspinal muscle damage

arm_group.description: Eight healthy volunteers (five males and three females) with a body mass index of 23.8 and without chronic metabolic disease or low back pain. They are all non-smokers and non-medicated.
Two MD catheters is placed in the paraspinal muscle at the level of midpoint of incision bilaterally. A reference catheter is placed in the deltoid muscle.

intervention.description: Two MD catheters with 1% lidocaine 1-2 ml are placed in the paraspinal muscle.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- patients who undergo conventional instrumented posterolateral lumbar fusion.
Exclusion criteria:
- previous fusion
- chronic metabolic disease
- tumor or metastasis
- postoperative surgical complications and complications during surgery
